title: Tuesday, 21st November, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:03am

Hi!

BE11:04am

So ..... what's been happening? How can we fill the next hour?

BE11:04am

Well ......... Over in Germany, we've got the "It's Thanksgiving Week And The Budget's Tomorrow So The News Is A Bit Thin" Crisis.

11:04 am
BE11:04am

https://www.ft.com...-9dbb-291a884dd8c6

BE11:04am

[T]he breakdown of talks on forming a coalition government, Germany is rudderless and the chancellor is facing perhaps the worst political crisis of her career.

BE11:05am

“I believe that the post-Merkel era has begun,” said Alexander Mitsch, leader of the Values Union, a conservative pressure group within the CDU. “Not only did she preside over that election debacle, she has also failed to form a government.”

11:05 am
BE11:05am

I'd have thought the post-Merkel era would begin post Merkel, but okay.

BE11:05am

I mean, I've read as many as two articles on German politics now, which obviously makes me an expert.

BE11:06am

And my impression is that the Jamaica coalition has collapsed but Steinmeier is pushing for avoid new elections and Merkel seems not interested in clinging on by minority so either the SPD winds in a bit and we get some kind of compromise on forming Jamaica 2.0 which judging by opinion polls would have public support or failing that we'll get another election that since Merkel seems to retain support within the CDU and the polls have barely budged since the September 24th election will likely be fought once again albeit somewhat reluctantly by Merkel.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

However, there might be some subtlety to the post-Merkel era that I'm missing.

BE11:06am

Have Citi.

BE11:07am

President Steinmeier now has an important role to play. He seems committed to avoiding early elections and ready to consider all possible avenues: (1) another try for Jamaica, (2) a Grand coalition for which he would have to overcome the resistance of his own SPD party and (3) a minority government. So far, the positions seem incompatible, with the FDP ruling out Jamaica, the SPD a grand coalition and the CDU a minority government. As polls so far do not suggest that the right-wing AfD is benefitting, new elections may seem less risky than awkward coalitions to many. However, the polls also do not suggest that elections would bring any new coalition options. We would still not rule out that there will be some movement this week, leading to new attempts to form a government. Important for political risks is the support for Merkel in her party which suggests she will stay to build a coalition or fight another election.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

And you can see the panic of a post-Merkel era by the eurozone sovereign spreads vs the Bund, where the drama so far has been microscopic.

BE11:07am

OAT spread narrowed by a whole 1 bip.

BE11:08am

BTP and Bonos spreads tightened by 3 bips and 4 bips respectively -- though the latter was because Linde at the Spanish central bank said economic growth will exceed 3% this year.

11:07 am
BE11:08am

So .... eh, SocGen incoming:

BE11:08am

Sell the euro? The German political paralysis will keep euro markets in thrall in the coming days after Chancellor Merkel ruled out a minority government hours after President Steinmeier yesterday called on all parties to go back to the negotiation table. Unless the CDU can coax the FDP or Greens into a lastminute minority coalition (or the SPD does a volte face on a ‘grand coalition’ with the CDU/CSU), the path ahead points to new elections next spring, which is uncharted territory and the least preferred option for markets. So far, angst about political vacuum has not scared away EUR equity or bond investors, whose mantra is presumably that the economy is growing strongly and tail risks are very low, with the ECB QE still providing ample liquidity support. But sentiment should turn against the EUR should new elections become inevitable. Whether and when President Steinmeier decides to dissolve parliament and call new elections is subject to Chancellor Merkel failing to get majority support in the Bundestag. The elections in Italy next year already have investors on alert, but the possibility of another political clash in Germany would make it difficult for EUR?USD to avoid a deeper correction from the September highs.

BE11:08am

And that, in a nutshell, is the "It's Thanksgiving Week And The Budget's Tomorrow So The News Is A Bit Thin" Crisis.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Which leaves you two options.

BE11:09am

You can head into the comment box of that Guy Chazan article above and have a moan around whichever interpretation of the news matches your pre-existing opinion.

BE11:09am

Or do what I'm going, and go scroll through the Hipster Merkel tumblr again.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

https://hipstermerkel.tumblr.com/

BE11:09am

Which -- inexplicably -- still hasn't won the Turner Prize.

undefined
11:10 am
BE11:10am

Okay, ROTR, you talk among yourself about railcards.

BE11:11am

Over this side of the page we'll do some stocks stuff.

BE11:11am

Of which, Imperial Brands seems to be as good a starting point as any.

11:11 am
Imperial Brands PLC (IMB:LSE): Last: 3,116, up 89 (+2.94%), High: 3,156, Low: 3,019, Volume: 1.85m
BE11:12am

It's that story again.

BE11:12am

Mostly on the confirmation that Japan Tobacco's promoted its current deputy CEO (and Executive Vice President, Business Development and Corporate strategy) to be the new group CEO.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

I think Nikkei reported this over the weekend, and JT put out a statement along the lines of, "hang on, shut up, we're not ready yet."

BE11:13am

(@littleclenches: you're getting caught in the spam filter. Don't take it personally. Someone will be along to fix shortly.)

BE11:14am

There's also a slightly different tone in his first public comments as CEO elect.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

"the company is actively looking for M&A opportunities"

BE11:14am

And .......

BE11:14am

"if there is a good M&A opportunity, company will pursue it regardless of size"

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Sorry, I should give him a name. I'm being inexcusably rude. Masamichi Terabatake.

BE11:15am

So, here comes this argument again. Jefferies.

BE11:15am

What is becoming very evident is that JT's current growth outlook is becoming increasingly pressured. The move appears to be focused on addressing this with the company flagging Mr Terabatake's strong global business sense as a key reason for him being given the role.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Addressing geographical exposure and RRP competitiveness key for us: Two key factors weighing on JT's outlook for us are its geographic exposure (Japan, Russia and Europe making up over 75% of tobacco profit) and its inferior RRP competitiveness (firstly due to its weaker heated tobacco product but secondly its lack of distribution in the world's largest reduced risk market of the US).

BE11:15am

Imperial for us still provides the most obvious solution: We have often argued that Imperial is the obvious answer to addressing the current structural pressures. While many said JT would not be interested in Imperial as it doesn't have a strong reduced risk proposition, this is missing the fact that it has national US distribution (even more important for us - JT may solve the product side but without distribution, growth in the US would be very difficult). Other strategic benefits include a significant cost save story that could support earnings while also providing funds for investment in reduced risk, while it would also give large-scale infrastructure in the Middle East and Africa where cigarette volume trends are still robust (JT has been trying to address this itself over the last few years with the shisha pipe acquisition in Egypt and the tie up with Ethiopian Tobacco). Imperial has the best positioning in Middle East and Africa across all global peers.

BE11:17am

The flipside of the argument is equally stale.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

As in, the Japanese state is legally required to maintain a one-third stake in Japan Tobacco.

BE11:18am

Can JT fund an offer for Imperial while also preserving its investment-grade rating? Maybe, but it'd likely take equity, and the state's one-third stake makes that kinda tricky.

BE11:19am

And it'd also mean JT backing out of its long-term policy of avoiding taking on any exposure to gaspers in the US, where it doesn't fancy the litigation risk.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

What we can say is that Imps was at a 52 week low at the close yesterday so today's bounce isn't entirely unexpected.

BE11:20am

While JT really needs to fix heated tobacco in its home market. Buying Imps doesn't do that.

BE11:21am

Apparently, JT only started selling Ploom TECH at the end of November and is suffering from shortages.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Expecting transformational M&A the day the new guy's name is announced feels a wee bit premature.

undefined
BE11:23am

Okay, then. Let's bump through requests.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Melrose going badly.

Melrose Industries PLC (MRO:LSE): Last: 200.60, down 14.7 (-6.83%), High: 208.50, Low: 194.70, Volume: 7.08m
BE11:23am

July to Oct trading update is fine at the headline, but Brush remains a problem.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

You've also got management's hard work sacking people being unwound a bit by FX and raw material headwinds.

BE11:25am

Shares getting hit because Brush 2018 margins are being taken back quite a bit. From 9% to about 4%.

BE11:26am

Which knocks about 4% off group profit, but also causes some problems for Brush's eventual disposal value.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:26am

Overall management states that trading in FY17 remains on track and in line with current expectations, although is highlighting some headwinds in FY18, which may signal pressure on expectations for FY18.

Melrose’s trading update for the four months to the end of October saw Nortek deliver 3% organic growth, an acceleration from the first half. This is broadly in line with our 2H17 organic growth estimate of 3.6% (revenue in the 10mths to the end of October saw OCC sales growth of +1% at Nortek). The three businesses within Nortek all continue to develop positively, though management is highlighting headwinds in 2018 caused by adverse FX impacts on Chinese imports and increasing cost of materials. Despite this, the board remains confident in achieving its objectives for Nortek.

The end market picture for Brush remains challenged, and has continued to worsen since 1H17. The current order intake would result in a “low single-digit margin during 2018”. Our current estimates for this business assume EBITA of £20.7m and a 9.0% operating margin in FY17E, followed by £23.2m (10.0% margin) in FY18E. Management continues to review its options for this business.

BE11:27am

And Cazenove.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

On Nortek, we leave our estimates unchanged in all years. We expect high-end estimates to pull back slightly for 2018 on the basis of the headwinds flagged. However, with FX and raw materials headwinds being offset in time and underlying trading conditions unchanged, we expect 2019 consensus for Nortek to be largely unchanged. An unchanged 2019 is also consistent with management’s unchanged view on Nortek’s longer-term prospects. For Brush, in the absence of details on the restructuring, we reduce our 2018 estimates inline with the commentary but expect this to be only a point in time change; management plans to significantly restructure and improve the business and we see our previous forecast level of profit (£20m+) potentially achievable once management has implemented its plans. We therefore expect to be reversing this downgrade in the future once we have clarity on the scale and timing of the restructuring. The net impact of our changes is 0%-5%-5% to our 2017/2018/2019 EBITA estimates.

BE11:28am

We update our Sum of the Parts valuation but our December 2018 Price Target remains unchanged. We leave our valuation methodology on Nortek unchanged but now use a ‘normalised’ £20m of adj. EBITA base for Brush reflecting the likely impact of the management actions to restructure the business. This results in an unchanged 250p price target consistent with our view that the fundamental value of the business has not changed despite the downgrades to our forecasts.

undefined
11:29 am
BE11:30am

And from power to power.

Aggreko PLC (AGK:LSE): Last: 875.50, down 94.5 (-9.74%), High: 900.00, Low: 855.50, Volume: 1.45m
BE11:30am

2017's fine. 2018 not.

11:31 am
BE11:31am

All to do with contracts ending, plus off hires.

BE11:03am

Good morning, hello, welcome along, hey. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily stuff with the things and the stuff.

BE11:33am

Spent most of last year talking about renegotiation of contracts in Argentina

11:33 am
BE11:33am

And most of the year before talking about Japan business being exceptional because they sold a bunch of generators post the tsunami that just ended up sitting in a shed unused.

BE11:34am

Who can guide us through the numbers? Citi, maybe?

BE11:34am

Rental Solutions performed well (9% growth vs 1% in Q2),
helped by some USD10m hurricane revenues, albeit initially with relatively modest margins due to high mobilization costs. Industrial grew 6% YoY, disappointing vs 23% growth in Q2, partly due to weaker trading in Qatar and Saudi Arabia. Utility suffered -15% revenue loss, same as Q2, due to repricing and off-hires. YTD order intake of 666MW, up from 1H 430MW, thanks to well flagged 200MW win in Bangladesh, but pipeline conversion remains weak. Zimbabwe off-hires 80MW from 200MW contract, which should go to Bangladesh. Overdue debtors remain problematic, but Utility DSOs have improved slightly from 1H 190 days.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Management retains FY17 guidance despite USD8m bad debtor
increase (YTD USD18m), helped by early termination fee, low mobilization costs and likely greater Q4 Hurricane profit contribution, leveraging deployed fleet.

BE11:35am

2018 Downgrades — from PBTA of £214m to £200m, below company provided consensus of £229m, due to off-hires in high margin Japan (2017E revenues of USD30m and EBITA of USD20m) and Argentina (2017E £20m EBITA contribution). Japan off-hired half of 148MW early, triggering termination fee, whilst rest should go in March 2018. Management expects Argentina’s 214MW to off-hire towards the end of 2017. Korea Winter Olympics and Commonwealth Games should provide some 2018 relief likely generating est. USD50m revenues and USD10m EBIT. We forecast 2018E group EBITA margin of 14%, well below target of 20%.

BE11:36am

And Morgan Stanley, off the conference call.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

FY 2017 PBT guidance includes an early termination fee in Japan and the 214MW contract in Argentina lasting longer than expected, which offsets the $8m increase in bad debt provisions. 2018 is the concern where off-hire guidance for FY17 remains c 30%, but likely to be greater than 30% now factoring in Japan and Argentina. The impact of the Japanese contracts coming off offsets the benefit from the provision increase this year of $18m, while the headwind from Argentina is £5m higher (as the contract ends) as it has retained the contract for longer in 2017. Growth in Industrial is disappointing given the strong growth in Eurasia (+72% and £20m of revenue in Q3) and no expectation for an increase in the growth rate in Q4, which will include $15m of the S Korean Winter Olympics.

undefined
BE11:38am

Babcock mentioned among the small handful of comments he have so far.

11:38 am
Babcock International Group PLC (BAB:LSE): Last: 724.00, down 30.5 (-4.04%), High: 780.00, Low: 699.50, Volume: 2.40m
BE11:38am

Numbers miss, outlook maintained.

BE11:39am

You'll remember Babcock came off pretty sharply along with the UK defence group post the Ultra profit warning.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

The argument being, I guess, that Babcock is exposed to UK defence budget pressures .... the counter argument being, I guess, that it's easier to cancel an order for a few underwater acoustic torpedo decoys than it is to cancel a shipyard.

BE11:41am

Anyway, response seems to be a weighting concern.

BE11:41am

As in, Babcock has more to do in the second half.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Also, per Goldman:

BE11:42am

[O]n FY19, the company expects a delay to the start of large new vehicle programmes to FY19/20 (Land segment) due to ongoing UK government review as well as a stepdown from Magnox (Nuclear) to affect revenue growth that year. We therefore expect a slight slowdown in revenue growth in FY19 vs. FY18 due to this (GSe: 5.5% in FY19).

BE11:43am

Margins were weaker than we expected, coming in at 10.5% vs our expectations of 10.9%; however this appears to be a 1H/2H weighting issue and the company stated that it expects the margin to improve in 2H, reiterating its margin outlook of broadly
stable margins for FY18. Revenue visibility remains strong, with 92%/59% of FY18/FY19 revenue in place vs. 2Q update: 89%/59%. The bid pipeline increased to £12.2bn vs £10.5bn at FY17, while the order book reduced slightly to to £18.5bn vs. £19bn at FY17 Cash conversion post capex was 60%, down from 79% in 1H17 driven by working capital, timing; management expects this to normalise by the end of the financial year.

Overall, while we believe that the reiteration of the FY18 outlook should be taken positively, the concerns around the slight slowdown in FY19 revenue growth could weigh on sentiment. However, we note that the shares have been weak YTD, down
21%, so it should be in the price.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Worth noting that BAE doesn't seem to he caught by the NSCR review thing.

BAE Systems PLC (BA.:LSE): Last: 544.00, down 0.5 (-0.09%), High: 545.00, Low: 540.50, Volume: 2.49m
BE11:44am

No readacross, apparently.

11:44 am
undefined
BE11:46am

Decent story on Reuters overnight about Cairn selling a 30 per cent stake in its offshore Senegal field to BP.

Cairn Energy PLC (CNE:LSE): Last: 218.00, up 11.2 (+5.42%), High: 218.00, Low: 212.00, Volume: 1.12m
11:47 am
BE11:47am

Quoting an advisor to Senegal's oil minister, which seems reasonably good sourcing.

BE11:48am

Also quoting a price of $600m, which looks about right.

BE11:48am

BMO runs the numbers ............

11:48 am
BE11:48am

We carry 563 mmbbls for the SNE discovery (CNE 2C 563
mmbbls, FAR Limited 641 mmbbls and Woodside 560 mmbbls). Phase 1 will target up to 240 mmbbls and an initial plateau of 75-125 kbopd with start-up in ~2022. We assume the higher quality, better-connected lower s500 sands will form the bulk of first phase volumes with 210mmbbls (30% Recovery Factor).

BE11:48am

Cairn has a 40% interest in the SNE field although the Senegalese government has the option to further back-in (Petrosen currently 10%) for an additional 8%. We value a 30% interest in SNE at $577mm assuming long-run oil price of $63/bbl from 2021.

BE11:49am

And to conclude ..........

11:48 am
BE11:49am

A disposal at this stage is also in line with Cairn's strategy
to commercialise exploration success although we see Senegal as an important part of Cairn's investment case so this would put more pressure on the upcoming Norwegian exploration programme

undefined
BE11:51am

This Gyg thing mentioned on the right ......

11:51 am
Gyg PLC (GYG:LSE): Last: 130.50, no change, Volume: 168.88k
BE11:51am

That's clearly not a live price. Live is down 12%.

BE11:52am

Though still above the 100p flotation. 113-116p.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Which makes it a success, relatively speaking, for Zeus Capital.

BE11:53am

Who raised £6.9m for it in July.

BE11:53am

(@VV75: has it? Didn't see that, sorry.)

11:53 am
BE11:54am

Anyway, "small delays" to work .........

BE11:54am

Hurricanes "resulting in disrupted cruising patterns and owners extending their Mediteranean season while they assessed the facilities in the Caribbean cruising grounds" .... which is fair enough.

BE11:55am

Plus "A substantial contract that was scheduled to start in late September has been delayed due to the vessel not arriving in dock until the middle of November", which is more interesting. Where did it go?

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Anyway, soft warning here: https://www.invest...1711210700060360X/

undefined
BE11:57am

(@Tom: there once was a guy who did fracking; his financial ability was lacking; when interest rates rose; all his assets got froze; so he ended up getting a sacking.)

11:58 am
BE11:58am

..... What can we pass the final few minutes with, then? Sellside?

BE11:59am

Someone was pushing Hunting this morning, which is up a bit.

Hunting PLC (HTG:LSE): Last: 528.50, up 16 (+3.12%), High: 532.50, Low: 518.50, Volume: 276.07k
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Kepler, that was it.

BE12:01pm

Hunting, an oil and gas services provider, is highly exposed to the US and is benefitting from the shale industry revolution there, as new technologies boost demand for its products. This is especially true for its completion activities. While we think its business model has some disadvantages (distribution centres, supplying bigger oil services companies), it possesses key technologies (e.g. H-1 perforating guns), a sound balance sheet, and we expect its top line and margin to improve markedly in 2017-20E. Although the significant share rebound since the low in early 2016 (c. 100%) already seems to price in part of the expected operating improvement, downside risks are low, and we still see further c. 30% upside. We initiate coverage with a Buy rating and TP of 640p.

BE12:01pm

The working's quite interesting even for those who don't give a monkeys about Hunting.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Through our proprietary model on the US shale industry, we
forecast that: 24,600 wells will be drilled in the US in FY 2020E
(c. 11,000 in FY 2016) and c. 2.4m fracks will be made in the US in
FY 2020E, a number well above FY 2014 levels (c. 1.3m).

BE12:02pm

After that, it's a lot of discussion of H-1 perforating guns. Speak to Kepler if that pulls your chain.

undefined
12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

That'll do, right? We've filled the hour.

BE12:03pm

(@GBKrona: sorry, haven't looked at it yet.)

BE12:04pm

Back tomorrow, when we can pick the up railcard chat again.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

https://www.ft.com...-9dbb-291a884dd8c6

BE12:05pm

Want Liberum, since it's just dropped into my email?

BE12:05pm

"We expect this budget to focus on small, headline-grabbing wins, as the Left’s popularity continues to dictate policy direction."

12:06 pm
BE12:06pm

As opposed to all the other Budgets delivering big, anti-populist losses, I guess.

BE12:06pm

Massive screendump incoming.

BE12:07pm

12:07 pm
BE12:08pm

Right click and open in new window to make that legible, maybe, if you want. Or not, if you don't.

BE12:08pm

Right. That's yer lot.

BE12:08pm

Back tomorrow. Afternoon all.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Japan and Argentina marked as the problem areas. And by the way, how many damn times have we flagged Japan and Argentina as the problem areas?
